runs.text: Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that this realistic fiction story is about a boy who has a creative solution to a problem. Have students point to the main character in the story.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
a robot that can help her do chores.
Have students whisper-read the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the name of the main character in the story. (Roy)
Why do Roys parents give him a soccer ball? Find the sentence that answers the question.
What does Roy invent? How does it help him get exercise while making music? Explain.
Would you like to use Roys toy? Why or why not?
Have students reread the story during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that this text is about observing fresh foods spoiling over time and growing mold. Have students predict which food will spoil the fastest.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the text.
is something that has been made harmful or poisonous.
with chemicals from the nearby factory.
How do you know if food is safe to eat? How can you tell if it is
Have students whisper-read the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the phrase that tells the purpose of the Rot Race. (to find out which food spoils quickest)
What should you do with the contaminated food after the experiment? Find the sentence that answers the question.
Why do you think that some food has more mold than other foods? Use details from the text to explain.
Have you ever eaten blue cheese? What did it taste like? If you havent eaten it, would you like to try it?
Have students reread the text during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Have students whisperread each sentence. Then ask them to chorally read it.
spellings. Have them point to and read those words to a partner.
Have students write a sentence using the word
. Have students read the sentence to a partner.
Discuss the different end punctuation for sentences 3 (exclamation point), 4 (period), and 5 (question mark).
Model how you change your intonation when reading a question (raise voice at end) or exclamation (read with emotion).
Then have students read the sentences consecutively.
Read the title. Explain that these are riddles. Each riddle contains clues about a toy. Students must identify the toy.
For the first reading, read the first riddle and have students read the other riddles. Invite volunteers to solve each riddle.
Then have students reread the riddles in pairs, alternating lines. Partners can switch lines during the rereadings.
Prompt students to find all words with
spellings in the text and circle them. Then have students chorally read the circled words. Ask students questions about the text to confirm understanding.
Say each word, guide students to write it, then proceed to the next word in the sentence.
Provide supports for words that are completely comprised of the phonics skills students have learned.
These supports include Sound Boxes, tapping the sounds, and so on.
Provide supports for the high-frequency words students have learned.
These supports include the Read/Build/Write routine.
When completed, have students read the entire sentence aloud.
Self-Correct: Write the sentences on the board, and have students self-correct. Take note of errors on each students Student Observation Form.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that students will read about things that are made from soybean plants.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the text.
means to have within or inside.
Think about the objects your school bag
. Which objects are most important? Why?
Have students whisper-read the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word in the title that has the
Why are so many things made from soy? Find the sentences that answer this question.
How are objects made from soy and objects made from plastic different? Explain.
How can you find out if an object contains soybean oil?
Have students reread the text during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.

Discuss phrasing, or how to chunk longer sentences into meaningful parts.
For example, as you read sentence3, pause briefly after

Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that this text is about reading nutrition labels on food packaging.
Have students point to the different parts of the label mentioned in the text, such as sugar and the other ingredients.
Guide students through a reading of the selection.
Prompt students to share what they notice and wonder when reading the text and looking at the nutrition label.

Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word. This is an on-level selection. It is provided to gauge where students are in their reading progress toward grade-level goals. Students might need to listen and follow along with the e-book for support before they read the book on their own.
Explain to students that they will read a fairy tale about a prince and a dragon.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
How do you feel if someone
Have students whisperread the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word that describes the princes problem. (noisy)
How does the dragon annoy the prince? Find the sentences that answer the question.
How does the relationship between the prince and the dragon change throughout the story? How do you know?
How would you have convinced the dragon to be less noisy? Explain.
Have students reread the story during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to the word.
Explain that this informational text gives facts and describes the purpose of having satellites in space.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the text.
power when wind pushes against their blades.
What other objects are used to
Have students whisper read the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the phrase that describes what the moon looks like. (a golden coin)
How do human-made satellites generate power? Find the sentence that answers the question.
How do human-made satellites help people on Earth? How do you know? Explain.
Do you agree that satellites are helpful eyes in our skies? Why or why not?
Have students reread the text during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
